content.raw:
There's a patch in cc37357 with the changes I propose. This changes the output of `gztopic bw /gazebo/default/physics/contacts` during the fire_hose.world from
~~~
Total[3.72 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[183]
Total[3.84 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[121]
Total[3.64 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[182]
~~~
to
~~~
Total[3.66 MBps] Mean[3.06 KB] Min[0.01 KB] Max[5.17 KB] Messages[184]
Total[3.88 MBps] Mean[2.91 KB] Min[0.01 KB] Max[5.17 KB] Messages[123]
Total[3.51 MBps] Mean[2.99 KB] Min[0.01 KB] Max[5.17 KB] Messages[181]
~~~
content.html:
There's a patch in cc37357 with the changes I propose. This changes the output of gztopic bw /gazebo/default/physics/contacts during the fire_hose.world from

Total[3.72 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[183]
Total[3.84 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[121]
Total[3.64 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[182]

to

Total[3.66 MBps] Mean[3.06 KB] Min[0.01 KB] Max[5.17 KB] Messages[184]
Total[3.88 MBps] Mean[2.91 KB] Min[0.01 KB] Max[5.17 KB] Messages[123]
Total[3.51 MBps] Mean[2.99 KB] Min[0.01 KB] Max[5.17 KB] Messages[181]

pullrequest.title: All pose messages are sent out in a single message every iteration

content.raw:
The unit magnitude (B, KB, MB) is based on totalBps. When I measure the bandwidth of /gazebo/default/physics/contacts in the firehose.world, I get the following:
~~~
Total[3.72 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[183]
Total[3.84 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[121]
Total[3.64 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[182]
~~~
There's a bunch of small packets in a short period of time, so the bandwidth is over 3 MBPS, while the messages are usually less than 0.01 MB. Perhaps we could use different unit prefixes for the bandwidth and message size?
content.html:
The unit magnitude (B, KB, MB) is based on totalBps. When I measure the bandwidth of /gazebo/default/physics/contacts in the firehose.world, I get the following:

Total[3.72 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[183]
Total[3.84 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[121]
Total[3.64 MB] Mean[0.00 MB] Min[0.00 MB] Max[0.01 MB] Messages[182]

There's a bunch of small packets in a short period of time, so the bandwidth is over 3 MBPS, while the messages are usually less than 0.01 MB. Perhaps we could use different unit prefixes for the bandwidth and message size?

content.raw: Could the units for total bandwidth be displayed as Bps (and KBps and MBps below)? I think the Mean, Min, and Max refer to message size, but the bandwidth should show units per time.
content.html: Could the units for total bandwidth be displayed as Bps (and KBps and MBps below)? I think the Mean, Min, and Max refer to message size, but the bandwidth should show units per time.

content.raw:
I'm seeing a weird behavior with the drcsim standpipe. It can be seen most simply with the drcsim worldfile [fire_hose.world](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/cd8bcc3df9645e7d058f7ce958d5a1e14bec0210/worlds/fire_hose.world?at=default) (ignore the fact that the default gravity in this world is pointing up). When I start gazebo unpaused, the standpipe, which is fixed to the world, renders at a weird angle and position. Using the move or rotate tool causes it to snap back to its correct position. It just seems to be initially displayed with the wrong pose? When starting gazebo paused, it is rendered correctly.

[Here's a video of the incorrect behavior](https://vimeo.com/55494541).
content.html:
I'm seeing a weird behavior with the drcsim standpipe. It can be seen most simply with the drcsim worldfile fire_hose.world (ignore the fact that the default gravity in this world is pointing up). When I start gazebo unpaused, the standpipe, which is fixed to the world, renders at a weird angle and position. Using the move or rotate tool causes it to snap back to its correct position. It just seems to be initially displayed with the wrong pose? When starting gazebo paused, it is rendered correctly.

Here's a video of the incorrect behavior.
